The anatomical organization and size of the insular cortex, which may be altered in psychiatric disorders.

The functional engagement of the medial prefrontal cortex in decision-making, emotion regulation, and social cognition.
The role of the medial prefrontal cortex in integrating cognitive and affective processes.
The region of the cerebral cortex responsible for planning, controlling, and executing voluntary movements.
The neural activity of the nucleus accumbens, which plays a central role in the brain’s reward system and reinforcement learning.
The role of the orbitofrontal cortex in decision-making, reward processing, and emotional regulation.
The branch of the autonomic nervous system responsible for rest-and-digest functions, counteracting the sympathetic system.

The neural pathways involved in processing reward, reinforcement, and motivation, including the dopaminergic system.
The network of connections involving the right anterior insula, associated with interoception and salience processing.
A large-scale brain network that detects and integrates relevant external and internal stimuli to guide behavior.
The somatosensory cortex is responsible for processing sensory information related to touch, temperature, and body position.
Striatum connectivity refers to the neural pathways connecting the striatum to other regions of the brain, influencing motor and cognitive functions.

chinese_label: 下皮层网络-腹侧注意网络
description: This connectivity network includes subcortical and attentional systems, influencing attention, alertness, and response to stimuli.
The substantia nigra is involved in the regulation of movement and is a key region for dopamine production, especially involved in Parkinson's disease.
The SCN regulates circadian rhythms, controlling sleep-wake cycles and other physiological processes tied to the day-night cycle.
The TPJ plays a crucial role in social cognition, including empathy, theory of mind, and self-other distinction.
Thalamocortical networks are critical for processing sensory information and modulating cortical activity, integrating multiple sensory inputs.
Thalamus volume can be used as a measure in neuroimaging studies to understand neurodegenerative diseases and neurological conditions.
The ventral striatum is involved in motivation, reward processing, and emotional regulation, often linked to addiction and mood disorders.
The VTA is important for the release of dopamine, influencing reward, motivation, and emotion, and plays a role in addiction.
The vmPFC is associated with decision-making, emotional regulation, and social behaviors, crucial for integrating emotional and cognitive processes.
Visual processes refer to the cognitive and neural mechanisms by which visual stimuli are perceived and interpreted by the brain.
ATP is the primary energy carrier in cells, essential for metabolism and cellular functions, including muscle contractions and neurotransmission.
ACTH stimulates the adrenal glands to produce cortisol, playing a key role in stress responses and regulating metabolism.
BDNF is crucial for brain plasticity, neuronal survival, and function, involved in learning, memory, and mood regulation.
CCK is a hormone that regulates digestion and appetite, also affecting mood and anxiety through its action on the nervous system.

chinese_label: 促肾上腺皮质激素释放激素
description: CRH is involved in the stress response, stimulating the release of ACTH and cortisol from the adrenal glands.
Cortisol is the primary stress hormone, regulating metabolism, immune response, and stress adaptation.
Cytokines are signaling proteins involved in immune responses, inflammation, and cellular communication.
Dopamine is a neurotransmitter that plays key roles in reward, motivation, and motor control, also linked to mood disorders and addiction.
The Dopamine D1 receptor is involved in mediating the effects of dopamine, particularly in movement, reward, and mood regulation.
Estrogens are a group of hormones that regulate the development and function of the female reproductive system and affect various other tissues.
GABA is the main inhibitory neurotransmitter in the brain, playing a key role in reducing neuronal excitability and maintaining balance in the nervous system.
Glucocorticoids are steroid hormones involved in regulating metabolism, immune response, and stress adaptation, produced by the adrenal glands.
Glutamate is the most abundant excitatory neurotransmitter in the brain, essential for synaptic plasticity, learning, and memory.
The glutamate-glutamine cycle involves the conversion of glutamate to glutamine in neurons and astrocytes, important for neurotransmitter regulation.
Inflammatory molecules are substances, such as cytokines and prostaglandins, that mediate inflammation and immune responses in the body.
Interleukin 1β is a cytokine involved in the inflammatory response, playing a key role in the immune system and autoimmune diseases.
Interleukin 6 is a cytokine that regulates immune responses, inflammation, and is involved in various disease processes, including autoimmune diseases.
Leptin is a hormone primarily involved in regulating energy balance and appetite by signaling the status of fat stores to the brain.

chinese_label: 神经元谷氨酸转运蛋白EAAT3
description: EAAT3 is a transporter responsible for clearing glutamate from synapses, helping to regulate neurotransmission and prevent excitotoxicity.
Neuropeptide S is involved in regulating anxiety, arousal, and wakefulness, influencing the central nervous system's responses to stress.
Neuropeptide Y is involved in regulating food intake, energy balance, and emotional response, particularly in stress and anxiety regulation.
Neurosteroids are steroids synthesized in the brain that modulate neuronal excitability and have neuroprotective effects in the central nervous system.
Norepinephrine is a neurotransmitter and hormone involved in the body's response to stress, as well as in regulating mood and attention.
Oxytocin is a hormone and neurotransmitter involved in social bonding, childbirth, and lactation, often referred to as the "love hormone."
PSD-95 is a scaffolding protein involved in synaptic signaling and plasticity, particularly in the postsynaptic terminal of neurons.
Serotonin is a neurotransmitter that regulates mood, appetite, and sleep, playing a role in psychiatric disorders such as depression and anxiety.
The serotonin-1B receptor plays a role in regulating serotonin signaling, particularly in the brain regions associated with mood and anxiety.
Synapsin-1 is a protein that regulates the release of neurotransmitters from synaptic vesicles, influencing synaptic plasticity and neuronal signaling.
Testosterone is the primary male sex hormone responsible for the development of male reproductive tissues, as well as promoting secondary sexual characteristics.
Thyroid hormones, including T3 (triiodothyronine) and T4 (thyroxine), regulate metabolism, growth, and development through their effects on cells.
Tumor necrosis factor-alpha (TNF-α) is a cytokine involved in systemic inflammation, playing a role in immune response and the pathogenesis of various diseases.
Vasopressin is a hormone that regulates the body's retention of water by acting on the kidneys, and also plays a role in blood pressure regulation.
The α2-noradrenergic receptor is involved in inhibitory neurotransmission, particularly in regulating the release of norepinephrine and influencing mood and anxiety.
